interpretations.description:
The Testament of Solomon
                
                    The "Testament of Solomon," a Greek text from the early centuries CE, provides the most
                    detailed account of the ring's use. It describes how Solomon used the ring to summon and
                    interrogate demons one by one, learning their names, powers, and weaknesses. Each demon
                    was then bound to a specific task in building the Temple or confined so it could harm
                    no one.
                

                Islamic Tradition
                
                    In Islamic tradition, Sulaiman (Solomon) was granted dominion over the jinn by Allah.
                    The ring allowed him to control winds, understand the speech of animals, and command
                    armies of spirits. The Quran describes how jinn worked for Solomon, building palaces
                    and diving for pearls. When he lost the ring briefly to a demon, his kingdom was thrown
                    into chaos until he recovered it.
                

                Western Occultism
                
                    Medieval grimoires such as the "Lesser Key of Solomon" claim to preserve Solomon's magical
                    knowledge. The hexagram or pentagram became known as the "Seal of Solomon" and was used
                    in ceremonial magic to invoke and constrain spirits. This tradition continues in modern
                    occultism and has profoundly influenced Western esotericism.

longDescription:
The Ring of Power That Commanded Demons and Spirits The Seal of Solomon is a legendary magical ring or signet that granted King Solomon
                    power over demons, jinn, and spirits. According to various traditions, the ring was
                    given to Solomon directly by God (or through the archangel Michael) and bore either
                    the ineffable Name of God or a sacred geometric symbol, granting him wisdom and
                    authority over the supernatural world.

extendedContent.content:
The Seal of Solomon is a legendary magical ring or signet that granted King Solomon
                    power over demons, jinn, and spirits. According to various traditions, the ring was
                    given to Solomon directly by God (or through the archangel Michael) and bore either
                    the ineffable Name of God or a sacred geometric symbol, granting him wisdom and
                    authority over the supernatural world.
                
                
                    With this ring, Solomon was said to have commanded legions of demons to help build
                    the Temple in Jerusalem, bound evil spirits, and gained knowledge of all things seen
                    and unseen. The ring became central to later magical traditions and grimoires claiming
                    to preserve Solomonic magic.
extendedContent.title: Description and Nature

extendedContent.content:
The Testament of Solomon
                
                    The "Testament of Solomon," a Greek text from the early centuries CE, provides the most
                    detailed account of the ring's use. It describes how Solomon used the ring to summon and

                    was then bound to a specific task in building the Temple or confined so it could harm
                    no one.
                

                Islamic Tradition
                
                    In Islamic tradition, Sulaiman (Solomon) was granted dominion over the jinn by Allah.
                    The ring allowed him to control winds, understand the speech of animals, and command
                    armies of spirits. The Quran describes how jinn worked for Solomon, building palaces
                    and diving for pearls. When he lost the ring briefly to a demon, his kingdom was thrown
                    into chaos until he recovered it.
                

                Western Occultism
                
                    Medieval grimoires such as the "Lesser Key of Solomon" claim to preserve Solomon's magical
                    knowledge. The hexagram or pentagram became known as the "Seal of Solomon" and was used
                    in ceremonial magic to invoke and constrain spirits. This tradition continues in modern
                    occultism and has profoundly influenced Western esotericism.
extendedContent.title: Legends and Traditions

bibliography: Duling, D.C., trans. "Testament of Solomon." Old Testament Pseudepigrapha. Doubleday, 1983.
Mathers, S.L. MacGregor, trans. The Key of Solomon the King. Weiser, 2000.
Peterson, Joseph, ed. The Lesser Key of Solomon. Weiser, 2001.
Torijano, Pablo A. Solomon the Esoteric King. Brill, 2002.
historicalPeriod: Late antiquity through medieval period (c. 1st century CE - present)

relatedEntities.name: YHWH
relatedEntities.relationship: Divine source of the ring's power

relatedEntities.name: Jinn
relatedEntities.relationship: Spirits commanded by Sulaiman in Islamic tradition

relatedEntities.name: Temple of Solomon
relatedEntities.relationship: Built with help of bound demons

symbolDesigns.hexagram: Six-pointed star (Star of David) - most common form of the seal, representing the union of opposites
symbolDesigns.pentagram: Five-pointed star - used in ceremonial magic traditions, representing the elements
symbolDesigns.divineName: Some traditions hold the ring bore the Tetragrammaton (YHWH) or Shem HaMephorash (72-letter Name)

jewish.origin: Given by God or through Archangel Michael
jewish.powers: Control over demons, wisdom, understanding animal speech
jewish.lostRing: According to some traditions, Solomon lost the ring and his kingdom briefly to Asmodeus

islamic.origin: Allah granted Sulaiman dominion over jinn, winds, and animals
islamic.powers: Control over jinn and winds, understanding of animal languages

westernOccult.development: Medieval grimoires claimed to preserve Solomon's magical system
westernOccult.keyTexts: Clavicula Salomonis (Key of Solomon), Lemegeton (Lesser Key)
westernOccult.practices: Ceremonial magic for invoking and binding spirits

associatedDemons.testamentOfSolomon: The Testament of Solomon catalogs 36 demons interrogated and bound by Solomon, each with specific powers and weaknesses
associatedDemons.lemegeton: The Lesser Key lists 72 demons (Goetia) that Solomon allegedly bound

sources.title: Testament of Solomon
sources.relevance: Earliest detailed account of Solomon's demon-binding (c. 1st-3rd century CE)

sources.title: Quran, Surahs 27, 34, 38
sources.relevance: Islamic traditions of Sulaiman and the jinn

sources.title: Clavicula Salomonis (Key of Solomon)
sources.relevance: Medieval magical grimoire attributed to Solomon
